boat.full_description:
A rare 21’ open day boat with gaff rig and cast iron centre plate, No. 11 of a series of GRP facsimiles of an original 19th century Yealm Crabber working boat.

Flirt was built by Newton Ferrers based Hockaday Brother in 1988 for John Powell and featured in an article on the Yealm Crabbers in edition 9 of Classic Boat magazine from the same year. Rigs varied, this example features a high peak gaff and short bowsprit. Sister boat Will'O-The-Wisp (2947) features a loose foot lugsail, Dovey Tryst (2531) a yawl configuration. The rig for Orca (3056) is unknown. Sail rigs were designed by John Wilkingson, creator of the Drascombe series and original sails (still fitted to Flirt) by Andrew Hooper.

The hull mould was taken from Shamrock a crabber built by John Hockaday in the late 1800's and purchased by his great great grandson's Harry & Jack Hockaday as forlorn motor launch Shula from local Jim Hill in 1976. The misshapen and dilapidated hull was repaired and reworked before a series of four Whaler rowing boats and lugg rigged Shamrock herself were launched at the village regatta in July 1979. The four Whalers still exist and recently refurbished are used at Yealm and Dartmouth Regattas. Shamrock with small cabin featured in local news in 2013 then owned by 'Sail Trade' delivering local produce from the Tamar valley to River Cottage at Plymouth's Royal William Yard.

Flirt was extensively overhauled and refitted following purchase Autumn 2019 benefiting from additional attention during the 2020 Covid lockdown. Now based on the River Dart and discovered to be a fast hull with powerful rig. These features tie in with the online conjecture that the original design was designed for quick access to offshore crabbing grounds some distance from the mouth of the Yealm. New sail cut with reduced gaff angle mainsail fitted 2022.

Winner of OGA photo competition 2020 (Social. Distanced) and featured on the OGA homepage in 2022 fitted with overboom tent on its Dittisham mooring.
boat.name: Flirt
reference: "Crabbers of the Yealm" Classic Boat magazine edition 9, 1988
boat.short_description:
No. 11 of a small series of fibreglass Yealm Crabbers built in the late ‘80’s by the Hockadays at Newton Ferrers from a mould taken from an original Crabber built by their forebears. All seem to have been fitted out with a variety of rigs although information about the type is scant.

Hull moulds also used for the Whaler rowing boats used annually at Dartmouth and Yealm Regattas.

Thorough overhaul and refit winter 2019 into Covid 2020 lockdown.

A fast hull design with a new powerful rig for 2022.
